title: Red eye (triage pathway)
disclaimer: For personal clinical reference only. Do not enter patient identifiable data.
If suspected open globe: shield, avoid pressure/IOP measurement, urgent senior review.

q1.help: Any blunt/penetrating injury, chemical exposure, foreign body, or post-op trauma.

t0.text: Concern for open globe / penetrating injury?
t0.help: Suggestive features: peaked pupil, uveal prolapse, very low IOP, Seidel+, severe subconjunctival haemorrhage 360Â°, misshapen globe, large corneal/scleral laceration.

o_open_globe.title: Suspected open globe
bullets: Do not measure IOP or apply pressure.
Eye shield; keep nil by mouth if surgery likely.
Analgesia + antiemetic; tetanus as indicated.
Urgent ophthalmology senior review / theatre pathway.

q2.help: Check VA early; compare to baseline if known.

o_t_vision_ok.title: Trauma + normal vision
bullets: Likely: subconjunctival haemorrhage or conjunctival laceration (after excluding red flags).
Still examine: cornea for abrasion/FB, AC depth, pupil shape, EOMs, and consider IOP if no open globe concern.

q3.text: Red flags after trauma? (RAPD, severe pain/proptosis, restricted EOMs, hyphema, abnormal pupil/iris shape)
q3.help: If RAPD or proptosis + tight lids, think optic nerve compromise / retrobulbar haemorrhage; if hyphema, manage as per protocol.

o_t_red_flags.title: Trauma red flags present
bullets: Check for RAPD and optic nerve function; consider retrobulbar haemorrhage if tense orbit/proptosis.
Anterior segment exam: corneal abrasion/FB, hyphema, traumatic iritis/uveitis, abnormal iris/pupil.
Escalate urgently / manage per local protocol.

next.label: If anterior segment findings excluded or insufficient

q4.text: Anterior segment cause identified (abrasion/FB, hyphema, uveitis/iritis, pupil/iris abnormality)?

o_t_ant_found.title: Manage identified anterior segment cause
bullets: Treat per local guideline (eg FB removal + antibiotic, hyphema precautions, traumatic iritis treatment, etc).
Consider dilated posterior exam if vision reduced, high-risk mechanism, or poor view.

q4b.text: Posterior segment concern or reduced view?
q4b.help: If no clear anterior cause, or mechanism high risk, dilate if safe.

o_t_dilate.title: Dilate and examine posterior segment
bullets: Look for: vitreous haemorrhage, choroidal rupture, retinal detachment or dialysis.
If poor view: consider B-scan / urgent senior input.

o_t_low_concern.title: Low concern after trauma with normal findings
bullets: Consider discharge with safety-netting if exam reassuring and VA normal.
Return same day if worsening pain, photophobia, reduced vision, new flashes/floaters, or increasing swelling.

q5.help: If yes, have low threshold to exclude microbial keratitis (corneal ulcer).

q5a.help: Pain, photophobia, reduced vision, corneal infiltrate/epithelial defect, AC reaction.

o_ulcer.title: Possible corneal ulcer (contact lens risk)
bullets: Urgent ophthalmology review; consider corneal scrape/culture per protocol.
Start treatment per local guideline; stop contact lens use.

q6.help: Measure IOP unless open globe suspected. High IOP can indicate angle closure or hypertensive uveitis.

o_high_iop.title: High IOP with red eye
bullets: Consider: acute angle closure attack / angle closure glaucoma; hypertensive uveitis.
Assess for corneal oedema, mid-dilated fixed pupil, shallow AC, nausea/vomiting, severe pain.
Treat/escalate urgently per protocol.

q7.help: Photophobia suggests corneal or anterior uveal pathology; severe boring pain can suggest scleritis.

q8.text: Anterior segment findings? (keratitis, anterior uveitis, hypopyon, blepharitis, scleritis/episcleritis)
q8.help: Use slit lamp + fluorescein; look for AC cells/flare; lid margin disease.

o_ant_found.title: Manage based on identified anterior segment cause
bullets: Treat per local guideline (keratitis/uveitis/scleritis/blepharitis etc).
If vision blurred without clear anterior explanation, consider posterior segment assessment.

next.label: If blurred vision persists / poor view

q9.text: Blurred vision without clear anterior cause?
q9.help: If yes, consider dilated fundus exam.

o_dilate_nontrauma.title: Dilate and examine posterior segment
bullets: Consider macular oedema (eg CMO) or retinal detachment depending on symptoms and exam.
If flashes/floaters/field loss: treat as retinal pathology until proven otherwise.

o_unclear_follow.title: No clear diagnosis yet
bullets: Re-check VA, fluorescein staining, lid eversion, and consider senior review if persistent symptoms.
Safety-net: return if pain/photophobia worsens or vision changes.

o_no_pain.title: Minimal pain / no photophobia
bullets: Consider: conjunctivitis, episcleritis, pinguecula/pterygium, blepharitis/meibomian gland dysfunction.
Treat/supportive care per guideline; safety-net if not improving or if vision changes.
